references: Based on the inspiration of data differential privacy, we apply this technology to the stage where the federated learning server receives each client model’s parameters and add a certain degree of noise to the parameters of the client model. Finally, the proposed federated learning algorithm with contrastive learning and differential privacy is shown in
. In each round, the server sends the global model to all parties to complete local training. The local models are received from each party, and the global model is updated using a weighted average.
We denote the number of rounds of federated learning training as
. Please assume that the WSIs data and its weakly supervised labels are distributed over
pair of WSIs data and the corresponding labels for the
is a single WSI. After data preprocessing and feature extraction, the data are represented as
and the local client’s neural network model
. W-Ave: Use the attention scores predicted by all patches as weights to average the feature embeddings of all patches. The parameters of the local model are denoted as
, and the parameters of the global model are
is an optimizer that updates the model parameters.
is a noise generator that can generate Gaussian random noise
is the standard deviation of the neural network weight matrix.

references: This section introduces the datasets used in prostate cancer diagnosis and Gleason grading tasks. Then, we describe the detailed data distribution and experimental setup. Moreover, we validate the effectiveness of federated learning on diagnostic and Gleason grading tasks. Furthermore, we compared
the difference in performance between FL and single-center models
the difference in performance between FCL and FL
. Finally, to make the model results interpretable, we use a heatmap to plot the cancerous regions identified by the model.

references: We use the loss functions and algorithmic models in each task from Section

. For example, we simulated the federated learning experiment with 8 Tesla V100 GPUs, where each card was treated as an independent institution.
We computed the validation metrics for each epoch to allow the model to converge to the best results.
The best-performed model on the validation set was used for the final evaluation of the test set. For both tasks, we conducted experiments with three settings:
1. Local learning, where each institution trains its data independently.
2. Global learning by aggregating the datasets of all institutions and training a multicenter centralized model.
3. Federated learning by training the data of all institutions without sharing the datasets but only sharing the model parameters.
For the diagnostic task, the data splits are shown in

.
The site: 0-2 remained unchanged. To verify the effect of data imbalance on the model, we split the dataset Site: 3-6 which has a large number of samples, into the positive proportion

.
Thus, there are seven institutions in the simulation experiment of federated learning. The dataset of each institution is randomly divided into training and validation sets according to the ratio of 80% and 20%. Stratified sampling is used to separate the dataset in each center to maintain the consistency of the class balance between the training and validation sets.
More importantly, to verify the robustness and generalization of the model on datasets that have not been seen before, we use datasets from two independent institutions for testing.
For the Gleason grading task, we simulated a six clients federated learning model and used an independent dataset from a private institution for testing.

On diagnostic and Gleason grading tasks, we evaluated the proposed federated contrastive learning model using a variety of classification metrics, including AUC of the ROC curve, F1 score, Acc, Recall, and Kappa score. In addition, we confirmed the feasibility of using differential privacy to protect WSIs data privacy.

references: WSIs can vary widely in morphological appearance due to differences in institutional standards and protocols for tissue processing, slide preparation, and digitization of pathological images. Therefore, it is important to generalize the model application to actual clinical data. We validate the robustness of the model using two external datasets. We found that models trained using federated learning on multiple institution data significantly improved the generalization performance of the models compared to models trained on single institution data. As seen in Table 5, taking α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5 as an example (see Appendix Table S1 for complete tables), both AUC and Acc are significantly improved in the diagnosis task. The average AUC of 7 clients is 95.59% when the categories are relatively balanced, and our federated contrastive learning model achieves an AUC of 97.25%.

.
The increasing Kappa score and AUC trend in the Gleason grading task are also pronounced. Since there are six categories in the classification task (6-level classification, i.e., ISUP 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5), the uneven data distribution will have more impact on the model. The average Kappa of six clients (site: 0-5) is only 0.74, while the Kappa of the federated contrastive learning model reaches 0.85, an increase of 0.11. The advantages of federated learning are apparent when the number of data categories is more extensive and the degree of data imbalance is greater.

references: Prostate cancer is the second most common cancer and the fifth leading cause of cancer death in men [1]. Generally, the golden standard for solid tumor diagnostics is the examination of Hematoxylin & Eosin-stained (H&E) Whole-Slide Images (WSIs) [2, 3, 4]. Diagnosis and Gleason grading of prostate cancer WSIs is crucial for clinical management and treatment of cancer [5, 6]. Expressly, Gleason grading is widely acknowledged as the most reliable method to evaluate the degree of prostate cancer invasion [7, 8, 9]. However, the interobserver and intraobserver variability of the Gleason scores are inevitable, and thus, it can lead to under- or over-treatment of patients in practical scenarios [5, 10]. In addition, manual diagnostic labeling of pathological images is time-consuming and expensive [11, 12, 13, 14].

To alleviate the Non-IID problem, FedProx [68] improved FedAvg by adding a proximal end to the local objective function, which helped enhance the method’s stability.
ComFed [58] utilized client-side variance reduction techniques to facilitate server aggregation and global adaptive update techniques to accelerate learning.
FedRS [60] proposed “Restricted Softmax” to restrict the update of missing class weights in the local process.
In FedDif [57], local models were diffused in the network to learn data distributions they had not experienced before global aggregation. After sufficient diffusion iterations, each local model accumulated the personalized data distributions of different used and obtained a similar effect to the training IID data.
FedDC [61] introduced a lightweight modification in the local training phase. Each client utilized an auxiliary local drift variable to track the gap between local and global model parameters.
Although the above methods have contributed to solving the Non-IID problem, the disadvantage is that they are only verified on ordinary natural images and are not suitable for large-scale pathological images in medical images.

This section introduces the datasets used in prostate cancer diagnosis and Gleason grading tasks. Then, we describe the detailed data distribution and experimental setup. Moreover, we validate the effectiveness of federated learning on diagnostic and Gleason grading tasks. Furthermore, we compared the difference in performance between FL and single-center models and the difference in performance between FCL and FL. Finally, to make the model results interpretable, we use a heatmap to plot the cancerous regions identified by the model.

WSIs can vary widely in morphological appearance due to differences in institutional standards and protocols for tissue processing, slide preparation, and digitization of pathological images. Therefore, it is important to generalize the model application to actual clinical data. We validate the robustness of the model using two external datasets. We found that models trained using federated learning on multiple institution data significantly improved the generalization performance of the models compared to models trained on single institution data. As seen in Table 5, taking α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5 as an example (see Appendix Table S1 for complete tables), both AUC and Acc are significantly improved in the diagnosis task. The average AUC of 7 clients is 95.59% when the categories are relatively balanced, and our federated contrastive learning model achieves an AUC of 97.25%.

This section introduces the datasets used in prostate cancer diagnosis and Gleason grading tasks. Then, we describe the detailed data distribution and experimental setup. Moreover, we validate the effectiveness of federated learning on diagnostic and Gleason grading tasks. Furthermore, we compared the difference in performance between FL and single-center models and the difference in performance between FCL and FL. Finally, to make the model results interpretable, we use a heatmap to plot the cancerous regions identified by the model.

WSIs can vary widely in morphological appearance due to differences in institutional standards and protocols for tissue processing, slide preparation, and digitization of pathological images. Therefore, it is important to generalize the model application to actual clinical data. We validate the robustness of the model using two external datasets. We found that models trained using federated learning on multiple institution data significantly improved the generalization performance of the models compared to models trained on single institution data. As seen in Table 5, taking α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5 as an example (see Appendix Table S1 for complete tables), both AUC and Acc are significantly improved in the diagnosis task. The average AUC of 7 clients is 95.59% when the categories are relatively balanced, and our federated contrastive learning model achieves an AUC of 97.25%.
